details.title: Lognormal selection with applications to lifetime data
details.standardTitle: Lognormal selection with applications to lifetime data

p: Thomas T. John received the B.A. degree in mathematics from Queens College of CUNY, and the M. S. & the Ph. D. degrees in mathematics from Syracuse University.

He is currently a Statistician with the Marketing Sciences Group at Knowledge Systems & Research, Inc. in Syracuse, NY. His current research interests include nonorthogonal, choice, and conjoint experimental designs; as well as applications of multivariate methods in market research.
Dr. John is a member of American Mathematical Society, Mathematical Association of America, and American Statistical Association.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Syracuse Univ., NY, USA
authors.name: T.T. John

p: Pinyuen Chen received the Ph.D. degree in statistics from the University of California at Santa Barbara.

He is a Professor, and the Director of Interdisciplinary Statistics Program at Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY. His current research includes statistical signal processing, and multinomial selection applied to voter preference problems.
Dr. Chen is a member of the American Statistical Association, and International Statistical Institute.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Syracuse Univ., NY, USA
authors.name: P. Chen

details.abstract: We consider selection problems on k lognormal (/spl mu//sub i/,/spl sigma//sub i//sup 2/) populations when the /spl sigma//sub i//sup 2/ are unequal, under both known & unknown cases. Selection based on linear functions of /spl mu/ & /spl sigma//sup 2/ are considered. For the unequal & unknown /spl sigma//sub i//sup 2/ case, a two-stage Rinott-type asymptotic procedure is proposed. In consideration to reliability & survival analysis applications, an asymptotic procedure is also proposed for the parametric selection based on the /spl alpha/-quantiles. Simulation studies to evaluate the procedures & to compare the latter procedure to the nonparametric procedure based on the /spl alpha/-quantiles are presented. The procedures are demonstrated using examples from reliability & quality control.

context.text: Sobel's nonparametric procedure (see [1])—Formulation 2A.

Results of some simulation studies which were performed to evaluate the new procedures from Section IV & to compare the parametric asymptotic procedure proposed for the selection based on \$\tau_{\alpha}\$ to the nonparametric procedures of Sobel [1] are provided in Section V.
Finally, the comparison of the parametric procedure \${\cal R}.4\$ for the selection based on the \$\alpha\$-quantile to the nonparametric procedure of [1] was performed.
A nonparametric procedure was developed by [1] for the selection of the \$t\$ best populations based on the \$\alpha\$-quantiles.
The nonparametric procedure in [1] is a single stage procedure with fixed sample sizes.
Also note that only the \$t=1\$ case in relation to [1] will be considered.

Notice that, when the populations are lognormal, and \$t=1\$, the preference zone for \${\cal R}_{\cal S}\$ is given by (see figure on p. 1806 in [1])and recall that the preference zone for procedure \${\cal R}.4\$ is given byFrom the above two inequalities, if we setwe obtain a relation between \$\epsilon_{1}^{\ast}\$, \$\epsilon_{2}^{\ast}\$, and \$\delta^{\ast}\$ for fixed \$\sigma_{(k)}\$ & \$\sigma_{(k-1)}\$.

A table of values of \$n\$ for \${\cal R}_{\cal S}\$ (recall this is only the formulation 2A of Sobel [1]) for \$\alpha=0.25\$, 0.5, 0.75 with \$\epsilon_{1}^{\ast}=\epsilon_{2}^{\ast}=0.2\$ are provided in Table VII.
We also note that the table for the \$\alpha=0.5\$ case provided in [1] was used to check for the accuracy of our computations.
Yet when considering the selection based on the largest \$\alpha\$-quantiles for small \$\sigma^{2}\$, the procedure seem to outperform the nonparametric procedure of Sobel [1].

links.abstract: Voltage collapse has been commonly associated with insufficient reactive power support. Steady state studies have related reactive power generation limitations to the sudden onset of voltage instability. This paper extends this approach to the dynamic case. The relationship between the dynamic models and steady state behavior is established. The dynamic model is then used to investigate the sudden change in system stability when the maximum excitation limit is reached. Several illustrative examp...

context.text: The density of \$X\$ is given bySome important quantities associated with \$X\$ & their relation to the parameters \$\mu\$ & \$\sigma^{2}\$ are \$EX=\exp(\mu+(\sigma^{2}/2))\$, \$E(X^{m})=\exp(m\mu+m^{2}\sigma^{2}/2)\$, \${\rm Median}(X)=\exp(\mu)\$, \${\rm Mode}(X)=\exp(\mu-\sigma^{2})\$, and the \$\alpha\$-quantile of \$X\$, \$\tau_{\alpha}=\exp(\mu+\Phi^{-1}(\alpha)\sigma)\$ where \$\Phi(t)\$ is the cumulative distribution function of the standard \$s\$-normal distribution [7].
Considering the applicability of the lognormal selection to reliability models, selection of the best from \$k\$ lognormal populations has been considered by [17] & [7].
The selection of the population with the largest expected value, under certain restrictions on some of the parameters, has been discussed by Gupta & Miescke [7].
It was shown in [7] how the lognormal selection with the above mentioned restrictions can immediately be done by a direct extension of the well developed \$s\$-normal selection theory.
See [7] for further details.

When the restrictions in [7] that either \$\mu\$ is known or \$\sigma_{i}^{2}\$ are known & equal are relaxed, the problem of selecting the lognormal population with the largest \$EX\$ is significantly different from the \$s\$-normal selection problem.
It is noted by [7] that “such problems…deserve to be studied more carefully in the future.” The present paper studies certain cases of such generalization.

See [7] for details on maximum failure rate & the time to maximum failure rate. \$\phi(t)\$ & \$\Phi(t)\$ are, respectively, the density & the distribution functions of standard \$s\$-normal, and the left side of (6) is the reciprocal of the Mill's Ratio.

links.abstract: An experimenter wishes to select the most reliable of K s-normal (or lognormal) populations. If he samples n items from each of the K populations, then how large should n be in order that he will have a desired level for the probability of correct selection? This paper gives tables which answer this sample-size question.

context.text: Considering the applicability of the lognormal selection to reliability models, selection of the best from \$k\$ lognormal populations has been considered by [17] & [7].
The issue of selecting the most reliable lognormal population at a specified time \$t^{\ast}\$ is the focus of [17].
Sample sizes required for this selection are given by [17].

context.text: Let \$\widehat{\eta}_{i}=\bar{Y}_{i}+m\widehat{\sigma_{i}}=\bar{Y}_{i}+m\sqrt{\widehat{\sigma_{i}^{2}}}\$, where \$\widehat{\sigma^{2}}\$ is the MLE of \$\sigma^{2}\$. \$\widehat{\eta}\$ is asymptotically \$s\$-normal with asymptotic mean \$\mu+m\sigma\$, and asymptotic variance \$(1+(m^{2}/2))\sigma^{2}/n\$ (see Cramér [23]).
